Posts.Content: My first chemo in August 14 damaged my veins in the way you describe I couldn't have a picc line as it was too severe and ended up with a Hickman which was inconvenient but saved so much pain with blood tests and the chemo I really don't understand why a picc is not done before chemo as it has definitely cost them more with me. I found it more painful than the operation arm and putting things like coats on and carrying was awful. Ive been referred to Physio twice tey do massage up the veins and exercise's similar to the post op stretches to start with then more stretching. I found I had to take paracemtamol before rads as the rad position was painful and I couldn't get my arm down the radiographer had to lift it down....but the arm behind the head position did help stretch the veins...after 2 chemo's it was up both inner arm and outer. I still have issues now with neck pain aggravated by lifting and then the arm starts to hurt. My oncologist and BC nurse did not believe it was more than phlebitis and gave me cream but the McMillan centre got me referred to Physio. They argued it wasn't cording, I don't really care what they call it but as it left big ugly cord like veins that were visible the length of my arm I'm not sure why its not cording. My arm now looks normal but I cant have bloods done without warming and a paediatric needle it then triggers arm pain. As does sitting at a computer or dining table chatting after a meal or a long drive.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: My first chemo in August 14 damaged my veins in the way you describe I couldn't have a picc line as it was too severe and ended up with a Hickman which was inconvenient but saved so much pain with blood tests and the chemo I really don't understand why a picc is not done before chemo as it has definitely cost them more with me. I found it more painful than the operation arm and putting things like coats on and carrying was awful. Ive been referred to Physio twice tey do massage up the veins and exercise's similar to the post op stretches to start with then more stretching. I found I had to take paracemtamol before rads as the rad position was painful and I couldn't get my arm down the radiographer had to lift it down....but the arm behind the head position did help stretch the veins...after 2 chemo's it was up both inner arm and outer. I still have issues now with neck pain aggravated by lifting and then the arm starts to hurt. My oncologist and BC nurse did not believe it was more than phlebitis and gave me cream but the McMillan centre got me referred to Physio. They argued it wasn't cording, I don't really care what they call it but as it left big ugly cord like veins that were visible the length of my arm I'm not sure why its not cording. My arm now looks normal but I cant have bloods done without warming and a paediatric needle it then triggers arm pain. As does sitting at a computer or dining table chatting after a meal or a long drive.
Posts.Title: Tight, painful veins after chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Beachhutter, I was diagnosed last year with T-neg had two ops chemo and rads. I think we all identify with the horrible scary journey but its doable. I managed to continue child-minding right through with 3 under 5 11 hours a day and the older ones one of whom is on the spectrum. So it may not be as bad as you think (fingers toes and all else crossed). I know that preparing your LO as much as possible is important and there are a lot of books and resources out there depending on his understanding. I explained that the medicine was making me better but was yucky stuff that meant I would be ill and tiered some days and even my hair was going to be poorly and not want to come out some days. The children would arrive saying its a pirate day today and took it much better than I thought. My Asperger's child is a hair twiddler and likes to hold mine too so this was an issue and I decided for that reason to have a short cut well in advance and avoided wigs when he was around. I wore knotted scarfs before losing my hair a bit so that he would be used to me wearing them. We also changed the way we played a bit so that he got used to me being less physically active and my partner took over this part and I did the quieter things reading singing etc. starting from diagnosis meant by the time I started chemo he was less worried about the changes he could see in me. The other children all took it in their stride as I prepared them for days I wouldn't be about (treatment afternoons and the following day mostly). Friends were great with offers of cooking shopping etc and I took every opportunity to rest. I'm the other side now and getting stronger everyday. Cancer is pants but its brought some positive change too. I made a commitment to spend more time on fun, I have new friends and don't waste time worrying about the ones who didn't want to know, I appreciate the little things much more and unlike the other types of BC my treatment has finished no more injections no side effects just a slightly new me with hair that is not the same as the old (now very curly) more eyelashes than I ever had before, my feet are soft due to the extreme chemical peel, and my stats are not too different to what they were before but I'm more aware and more conscious of my breasts so more likely to spot anything in the future. Yes I have down times but not too many an getting less so all in all life is not bad. I hope the comments that are posted will help everyone about to start out on the path. x
Posts.Title: Any Triple Negative survivors willing to calm me down!!??

Posts.Content: Waffle, have you got to have more Tax? I would ask to see the real Oncologist before I was given an extra week to see if feeling returned but in that time it didn't and I was wondering if I was imagining it until I got out of shower to find I had a toe nail that had cut my foot and I didn't even feel it. The Onc said as the side effects were accumulative I was likely to get more loss on each round and as it hadn't recovered it was better given my odds not to take the risk. I also had 2 days od blurred vision which they said would get longer each time, something I didn't fancy as I could not read or watch tv let alone drive. T was only giving me 1% so an easy decision but obviously everyone is different. Istill get tingling eventyping and doing fiddly things like necklaces and watches is hard.
Posts.Title: Numb toes

Posts.Content: I've had this since my first T, it was the reason that I was taken off treatment as unusual to get in round one and an extra week did not resolve it. I'm a year on and still have it in my fingers and toes. The cold makes it more painful. I would check by ringing your BC nurse.
Posts.Title: Numb toes

Posts.Content: "Bet your glad you don't have to dry your hair when you get in".....mum on the school run. I wish I had a wig,Â such a pain washing my hair.....really Ill swop. Radiographer...."nobody will laugh at you if its crooked (wig) they have all got cancer out there" I feel so much better then
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: I ring my BC nurse direct if I have any issues so If I were you I would ring and say the breast has deteriorated and you need the surgeon/onc to see you again. Insist you get an appointment even if you say you can feel something in order to get it and take your photos with you. My GP openly says they are not trained to identify or deal with issues after BC and I should contact my bc team so anything boob related goes to them for 5 years. I is awful to keep getting these knock backs I've recently had to have another biopsy a year after finishing treatment and go for results tomorrow. Just have to keep going and trust the issues lessen in time. Mentally its so tough.
Posts.Title: Any one got experience of inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: The tattoos don't have to be sever or unnatural but the fashion is for strong eyebrows so they tend to be what is shown most. They build them up bitÂ by bitÂ until you like them. But use someone used to doing normal brows not high fashion.
Posts.Title: Eye brow regrowth.

Posts.Content: Cant help with any cures. The eye brow tattooing is not a permanent Tattoo it only does a few layers of skin so lasts around 18 months depending on how you look after them. They can look very natural but are not a cheap option. I guess it depends how much you struggle with drawing your own. You can get stencils to help you with shape.
Posts.Title: Eye brow regrowth.

Posts.Content: sazzyp Hi vonnie Â I have had similar problems with my fingers and hands, I couldn't grip things and had no strength, I also had bad pains in my arms elbows and ankles, these started when I started taking tamoxifen 9 months ago . My consultant is adamant it is not the tamoxifen but after affects of the chemo therapy ? Not sure I'm convinced but it has eased off enough for me to go back to work now x It comes and goes more now x Sara Â x I'm t neg so don't take anything like tamoxifen now but have no strength in hands and numb fingers and toes. I get chronic pain in shoulders and hips and severe neck pain that wakes me every night and gives migraines. I'm told its due to surgery and chemo and have physio and acupuncture as well as Amatriptolyne
Posts.Title: hands, wrists and shoulders

Posts.Content: I had this happen. In surgery they knew they had got one node but after the test were done none were there. I had to go in and have a second op and all nodes were taken. They turned out not to be effected. I went on to have chemo and rads because I am triple neg so that would have been my treatment anyway.
Posts.Title: radiation to axillary

Posts.Content: I was told to use Lactulose. sennakot or movicol
Posts.Title: lactulose ? domperidone?

Posts.Content: 6 sessions of acupuncture with a noticable reduction immediately and almost gone by number 3 left me flush free for 18 months. They have just started to creep back a couple of times at night so have now had 2 boosters and all gone again.
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: I had 2 rounds of fec into my arm the vein damage was sever after the first round and they couldn't get a picc in. It felt like tight cords running up arm and into arm pit the doctor said it was phlebitis too. I was unable to straighten my arm ....rads position was agony had to take pain killers but did help movement as it stretched the veins. I've had physio courses twice now and waiting to see the pain clinic. I finished treatment 2 years ago and now get neck pain and headaches due to the damage. I would ask for your bc nurse to refer you to physio straight away and do all the exercises that you had on your operation side on your chemo side as well as massaging the veins.Â
Posts.Title: Arm pain after Chemo

Posts.Content: 6 sessions of acupuncture with a noticable reduction immediately and almost gone by number 3 left me flush free for 18 months. They have just started to creep back a couple of times at night so have now had 2 boosters and all gone again.
Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: I don't know your answer but have to say nothing is trivial if it effects your quality of life and robs you of normality. Hope you find your answer.
Posts.Title: Trivial I know in the grand scheme of things but....

Posts.Content: I think the dressing others mention is called Polymed, its fantastic I went from misery to being quiet comfortable. It is expensive which is why they don't like giving it and they do try only a tiny bit but it comes in bigger almost a4 sheets which if your a G cup like me you really need. It cushions your bra if you need to wear one which helps you feel normal to and unlike the gels keeps things dry. It was amazing how quickly the whole area improved so don't despair.
Posts.Title: After radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I had temperatures right through along with hot flushes the doc admitted me twice to rule out neutropenia ice packs or a chillo helped me. my temp would fluctuate widely up past 39 then back down and from ear to ear. Â I used diflame mouth wash that kept infection at bay but the white tongue wasn't a good look.
Posts.Title: Triple negative survivors , taxotere survivors shout out

Posts.Content: Its worth investing in a Chillo for night, its a cooling pillow pad that doesn't not need to be put in freezer. I also had acupuncture through a referral from bc unit to NHS physio which has virtually cured them, but this is probably only any good once you've finished treatment.
Posts.Title: Remedies for chemo induced hot flushes

Posts.Content: Physio will give you more exercises building on the post surgery ones to regain strength they also use oil and massage up the vein quiet firmly I was advised to do this twice a day and it has helped the tightness and appearance . Because I didn't get physio in treatment and being larger along with the issue of not being able to get a good supporting bra it has caused kneck issues as you hunch forward with the tightness so sitting correctly and bringing head back into line despite the pulling helps. I had rads after and took painkillers to get into the position which although painful did a lot to relieve the arm tightness over the18 sessions.
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: I had round on ein the arm then went for a picc which they couldn't do as veins were too damaged so ended up with a Hickman. I work as a child-minder and was able to carry on the line never caused an issue with the children. I strongly think everyone should have the option before fec....im now 2 ear past chemo and still have arm and kneck issues even after 2 physio referrals,
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: Totally agree with the others Idbe calling my bc nurse saying I don't understand and need an explaination asto why you feel you have been told effectively you have 2 years shake the s..t out of it and get tem to bring you back fro a full explaination of what was said with an other consultant.
Posts.Title: Confused after unhelpful consultant appointment

Posts.Content: Lynne1955 Hi I had a mx and sentinel node biopsy (they took 3 nodes) in oct 2015. Â I could lift my arm above Â my head after the op before I left hospial no trouble so I think it does depend on how many nodes they remove. Â I too was worried about drying my hair. I think if they find any of the nodes positive they then take more away and that is when the need for exercises kick in. Â I might be wrong and was lucky I dont know. Lynne No you were lucky...I had one node removed first time an awful problems as dressing was pulling and restricted movement, had to have a second op to do a clearance of nodes and was exercising on ward no problems since.
Posts.Title: Trying to be practical

Posts.Content: Gosh if I had done that I would have had a very bottom heavy curly grey afro I must have had at least 3 inches if not more cut off...shaggy mop look would not have mad me feel good at all. I would post my hair history but don't know how to upload pics.
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: My hair is finally straight enough to look normal has been a year since last chemo and about 7 cuts.
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: I never lost the hair around the back so despite having it cut to a number 1 it has always been thicker and longer than the top...really strange if you leave it so have kept having it trimmed so top catches up with sides and because the back and sides keep growing thicker in a sort of weird clown shape so every 4 or 5 weeks a trim. It did go really curly so the repeated trims have cut some of that out too. The last cut has left a fringe that now looks like it was meant and a shape that is sort of longer picky my next step is to hopefully continue growing the top, so yes about 7 cuts/trims once you have the first one you do feel better. I went to a Toni and Guy strength in style at first as they cut it in a private room so felt better than out on the main shop floor.
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Hi, I also had FECT, I don't have young children anymore but work as a child-minder with 3 under 5sn 55 hours a week. Obviously everyone is different and you can be unlucky to in both reaction and infection. I was able to work right through treatment with support. The first round was worse as they needed to tweek side effectsÂ so I took a day off then did things like the reading playing tables, my co minder did the school runs. Week 2 and 3 I worked as normal but took an afternoon nap. I did get more tiered by the end of 6 cycles and did less physical running around, no housework and dinner was down to the husband. I did wear gloves if doing nappies (as normal) and noses washed hands a lot more and had antibac gel. Also very thorough cleaning door handles etcÂ as children can forget to wash hands and although you send them back they have already touched it. My own towel. Other than that carried on as normal except watching where I ate out and no prepared salads. My parents were great and did keep children away if they showed any sign of being ill, but that was only a couple of days.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and child care

Posts.Content: My chemo was also in my good arm, very frustrating as left two bad arms. There are some articles on chemo induced cording and I have been told by one team it is cording and another Phlibitus. It certainly feels like a cords to me as I can feel them from md forearm up into arm pit andÂ  from wrist to elbow. Initially the restriction to movement felt like in my lumpectomy arm. For a time I had sharp pains in shoulder probably caused by lack of movement, and pain and bra induced bad posture.
Posts.Title: Sore veins post chemo

Posts.Content: I had 2 rounds of fec in my arm...round 1 did too much damage for the picc...it was very sore and more uncomfortable than bad arm you could see and feel tracks up to the arm pit. I was told it was cording and given physio massaging veins up to arm pit and exercises on top of post op ones. the rads position also helped but I had to take painkillers and they lifted my arm down. A massive improvement in about 6 weeks. I can now see the marks as I know they are there but others don't and the arm works normally....im going to ask for bloods elsewhere if I need them in the next 6 months.
Posts.Title: Sore veins post chemo

Posts.Content: Hi I've had this having had 2 fec in the arms back in August. I was given no advice and have only just started physio. You can see the lines of veins and some raised swelling around them worse when stretched. You can feel a hard line vein up the arm on both effected areas and one goes into the arm pit. Advice from physio was to do the same stretches as post op and to massage up towards arm pit along vein. Heat can cause lymphodema apparently. Some say this is cording and others chemo induced phlebitis, but it feels horrible in what should be the good arm....the rads arm position was painful at first so took pain killersÂ 20 mins before but in long run helped with pain raising arm. Annoyed this has caused pain and discomfort when a picc line before chemo would have avoided it...my veins were too bad for a picc after round one so had a Hickman. I can now reach upwards and put on coats but need to build strength. Lifting is still a bit uncomfortable but better since Christmas when I couldn't carry a bag I can now manage moderately weighted ones....maybe my husband paid them to avoid me spending too much. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Sore veins post chemo

Posts.Content: I would discuss options but if they do want to go into that arm....they did for my Hickman, I would make sure it is warm I went in with a hot pack on my arm the second attempt and it went straight in. As you have no chemicals going in I don't think it will do more damage the issue will be finding a vein which will be easier if its warm and you try to relax.
Posts.Title: Sore veins post chemo

Posts.Content: I would definitely have the Picc, Fec Fec'd my veins on the first round and was too bad to have a picc so secondÂ  fec and awaited a Hickman line. I'm now a year past chemo and still have problems in chemo arm initially was like cording that needed physio for months and was worse then the after op arm. Recently had bloods and it was a struggle with a paediatric needle she only just got enough out and then I have had a month worth of pain. I really believe everyone should have a picc line offer before starting.
Posts.Title: Start of journey part 2

Posts.Content: I finished chemo 2 years ago. Round one of fec damaged my veins too badly for the planned picc and round 2 made more damage to other veins in my good (said laughingly) arm. The immediate problem was much worse than anything on my bad arm unable to put my own coat on, to stretch my arm, lift things, general painÂ etc. As others describe you could see several ugly ruched veins running the length of my arm and up into my arm pit worse when arm was straightened. Differing opinions from doctors - Â phlebitis, cording and general damage but to me it looked likeÂ several Â cords and was very painful. I found taking Paracetamol and lying in position for rads did help release the veins a bit over my 18 session course - it was painful especially at first and I had to have help to lower my arm. Massaging by physio up the vein over about 10 weekly sessions has improved the appearance and pain in the arm itself. I am now left wit chronic neck and shoulder pain radiating from the arm pit and task like carrying shopping, typing and driving aggravate it. The pain clinic say I should have had help sooner as now the nerves are having their own party, If I were starting on this again I would not have chemo before a picc, If I missed that I would be going for physio or massage as soon as I could ideally during chemo....and the stretching exercise's are a must even when your feeling like you have been hit by a steam roller..
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: I'm still suffering from vein damage done by round 1 which meant I couldn't have a picc and had to have a Hickman getting bloods before the Hickman took a nurse and a doctor 3 hours and only just got enough. I still can have bloods from that arm even with a paediatric Â needle and they need to use my leg so for me the answer would be yes have it the pain from what feels like cording in the chemo arm and ensuing kneck problems are one of my main ongoing issues 18 months after chemo. Initially it was more painful than either of the lymph node ops I had.
Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: My best support came though my McMillan centre who referred me to their physio team.... what were you supposed to do with the sugar? I was given massage from the hand up along the veins to the arm pit using oil and firm pressure to stretch the veins and advised to continue twice daily between appointments ...you cant do it as well on yourself as you need to apply quiet a lot of pressure and the arm needs to be relaxed and straight....but anything is better than nothing. Things were main worse for me because being big busted and not being bale to ware supportive post op bras due to swelling and pain which made my posture worse rounding shoulders (along with the hickman line making a protective stance) thisÂ didn't encourage the veinsÂ to stretch eitherÂ hence the neck and shoulder pain.
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Normal good hygiene but if others are cooking who don't know make sure they understand mixing raw foods cloths etc. I carried on working so had 3 under 5's and 3 older childrenÂ  days a week including nappies and a dog. Managed to avoid infection with regular hand washes, gloves for nappies and disinfecting door handles etc. I ate out a few times and used my regular take away for the odd fish and chips.
Posts.Title: Risk of infection

Posts.Content: Yes Rach all my problems are in my chemo arm....stretching does help I found if I carried shopping it hurt a lot but did gradually stretch the vein as did the rads position...the massage is more direct. I've also had acupuncture for the neck pain which helped a lot and they put some in for the hot flushes which totally went for just over a year ...going to have a booster as getting the odd one back now.
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: So annoying to get so far and run into this.....I had a line in after my second fec they tried a picc but the damage was too bad so had a Hickman. It really wasn't too bad and made bloods and chemo much easier really cant face anything else into my good arm now as its still painful now. So was glad to have it done. My last bloods form the arm took all afternoon and they still didn't get enough the next day I went in having drank constantly but the biggest thing was having the arm in a hot pack all the way to hospital so it was really warm they also said once you have a few issues your body goes into fight or flight and the veins shut down so trying (ha ha) to relax helps. Hope it goes well I would personally say go with the line to stop more damage and keep stretching the good arm so the veins don't tighten and cord which is what has happened to me ...the surgeon recommended putting hand behind head as a good position...practice for rads too. Â all the best x
Posts.Title: Help ..... my veins are giving up !

Posts.Content: Im tneg so no hormone treatment for me and hadn't had a hot flush for 2 years.
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: I brought a Chillo which is a cooling gel pad that really helps....its self cooling so you can keep it by your bed. I have now had acupuncture through my local cancer centre which has almost illuminated them.
Posts.Title: Feeling hot and cold at night

Posts.Content: Gosh Tilly I member having that feeling especially when putting on makeup it. I thought I looked like the man from little Britain too. Making sure you let air get to your hair and massaging the scalp is supposed to help too. x
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Have you told them you still feel so sick. I was allergic to Domperidone had Emend and hour before and for 2 days, Ordansitrone and then Cytrezine for any break through nausea...the steroids made me feel ill to so had them reduced and felt fine after that.
Posts.Title: That awful nausea!

Posts.Content: I'm dreading my next one as it falls around my daughters birthday 21this time, and my wedding anniversary I asked them if I could move it and they said no. really feel like its a blight on my life waiting for 10 weeks from May and will ruin the early summer.
Posts.Title: Annual Check up

Posts.Content: Whilst I like everyone appreciate the fundraising need and am aware some choose to shave to raise funds I don't feel the explanationÂ  given by McMillan team sufficient, yes it raises loads etc but Brave nope. My sister was very close to me during treatment and very understanding, my Aunts husband died after having treatment etc. But both could not understand that the advert raised such a feeling of upset and distaste in me until I explained it and initially had thought it a good idea. Are the campaigns tested on a large sample of Cancer patients and survivors or a small sample well past treatment because no doubt your feeling towards them will alter according to the time laps from treatment?
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I think anyone who hasn't gone through it really doesn't understand hence the only temporary, you do have a beautiful face/smile blah blah comments when your feeling about as feminine as the man in little BritainÂ ,the steroid bloat robs most of us of any chance of carrying off the pixie faced waif look achieved in the films who rarely seem to loose eyebrows and eyelashes. Its hardly brave to shave your head to stubble knowing in a week or two your oing to have hair when most of us are still fighting the curly white afro look 15 months later or the fear that I'm going to be the one who doesn't get any back at all.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Seeing a shaved head still reduces me to tears a8 months after chemo. I don't think it helps anyone understand loosing hair from treatment as its something they have thought about and been around collecting money for so everyone who matters knows it a charity thing and it was their choice not an outward sign of what else is happening in chemo. To me its belittling and making a fun social occasion of what is one of Â the most mentally painful part of treatment, having had someone say I know what it s like to loose your hair I had mine shaved for charity would be a slap in the face to me. Wore than the it will grow, its only temporary or its saving your life comments.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I totally get people don't know what to say but I'm not alone in hating those comments and do wish they would think first and maybe just hug or ask how it's going than make light...you wouldn't say to a one legged man at least you have the other one... I do have hair now and it's a style and coloured...when it was short and white everyone said it looked good....and a few dame judi comments...as I'm 30 years her junior don't get how that's a compliment even though she's a fantastic lady....now they say I'm looking better than that grey....yep I guess they really loved it and I believe every word... But I digress I may have liked my hair now if I had chosen it. I didn't so it is more like having a hairdresser put right another's error...not what you choose so another loss of control. ..people who shave choose to do so they don't understand the helplessness of loosing control of life. But my previous post was more about my husbands feelings and why he gets the reaction to the campaign.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I've also gone for Judy's option 4 and explained to surprised reactions why so many of us hate the campaign. I still haven't met anybody who has travelled that part of the journey who supports the campaign.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: As I see nobody has said they like the campaign, hopefully they will reassess their whole ideology of scaring people into donating and or making light of the side effects by shaving heads with so many of us being affected that's about 50% of the donating public they are potentially alienating. they should be educating people on living with side effects so idiots in shops don't humiliate and laugh at us not turning hair loss into a party show piece.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Totally agree Judy. Im 2 years past treatment and can cope with weepy cancer films, all the ads for jump off things, cycle, bake or anything else out there but don't get why anyone would want to push the lets show we understand card by shaving our heads its rather sick to be honest don't mimic me any more than if I gave you money to stick a needle in your arm and try the chemicals. Your not making me feel better or getting a better understanding. If they want to raise money raise in other ways, if they want to give an idea of how it feels have short clips of how I felt when I lost my eyelashes, nails came off or any thing else but don't pretend they now know how it feels. The one thing I find most of a reminder of all the s... is seeing others in scarfs and knowing what they are going through, seeing a lady with short cropped hair and thinking that was me, it reduces me to tears. Even my husband reacts to it. Maybe its different when treatment is further away and maybe I will desensitise, maybe the people on the panel already have reached that point....but many of us haven't and no money raised is worth the mental torture these ads or seeing the fundraisers shaved heads put us through.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: While getting ready for treatment in those scary days of not knowing I was out at Hampton Court flower show with my husband keeping my at risk arm covered fearing sun burn etc. There were ladies in scarfs ladies withe close cut hair but not the outfits to match we talked about how I would look etc. It was emotional for both of us. I know my husband doesn't like short hair it made my feelings harder to deal with. He had a heart attack while I was undergoing treatment which may have made him more empathetic but now when we're out he gets when I'm feeling I was like that 18 months ago.Â  Loosing your hair when it's not your choice is never the same as choosing to have a hair cut. Having people say it looks good makes no difference when it's not your choice. Fearing a slipped wig wondering about boys giggling behind you is nothing like choosing to shave your head and waving wow I'm great look what I did for cancer...is nothing like having no choice or having cancer or understanding how it feels....which is why we all get so upset at the glib phrases like it's saving your life, it's temporary, but you've got such pretty eyes....
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: It depends what bra size you are I couldn't go without any support as a G cup and it pulled to much on stitches so invested in a couple of the bravissimo nightwear tops...soft cup but look like t shirts. I also got a couple of cheap non wired bras thatÂ I could cut the straps on as I had so much swelling all bra straps were too short...I then made them longer with ribbon. I would avoid anything that goes overÂ  the head as it can be hard to move. Also due to swelling it can be worth getting a bra extender as then as you go back to normal band size you can revert to you normal bra size...I went up from a 36G to a 40E. The drain tube just fitted inside the bra and up over the top. You may not have it in I didn't first time second op was all nodes so had it overnight. Definitely do your exercises even if you need painkiller first.
Posts.Title: what to wear

Posts.Content: I agree Birty, I've had surgery chemo and rads and worked pretty normally through with odd times off It definitely helped keep my mind off poor me and on the whole ive felt upbeat and confident it took about 5 to 6 weeks to recover from chemo tiredness but n problem with rads and tiredness or making appointments as I didn't have to get back into getting up and getting there it just felt normal Im now in my 3 months from finish and feeling pretty old me except for odd discomforts in scar and occasional reoccurrence worry. So for me it was 100% the right thing obviously I had some illness and 2 hospital visits so not al plain sailing but if like me work is a major part of life I think its a goo choice.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Every time I see one of the specialists things seem to change. I thought Id come to terms with having FEC and felt could cope now I've been told that by having FECT I can improve my odds by 1 to 2 %. They did say that it was harder than FEC but not much more detail so now I've looked at the leaflet I'm feeling really wobbly about it. People seem to be saying FEC was do able etc.but nobody is seeming as positive about the T bit...I know positive may not be the write word.. My head is buzzing with the side effects I already have pain in my hips that nothing takes away the thought of it all over for months along with everything else that could be a side effect just seems to be freaking me out..my mum was in a wheelchair with severe arthritis and my sister who is 8 years old is now not far off. Â  Has anybody any positive ish experiences?
Posts.Title: Worried about the Tac side of my Chemo.

Posts.Content: Sometimes telling people and repeating your self can be exhausting. Especially going through treatment I set up a Facebook group private to my friends who wanted to know which meant me or OH just updating now and then people could read comment etc but I was under no pressure to repeat or talk when I didn't want to. Some were not on Face book so a friend passed on updates Left me selecting wen I spoke to people and I could just leave it At yes getting through how's the family when I wanted just normal life conversation. A long bumpy road but yes do able in whatever way your body allows be kind to yourself . x
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: I would call your bc nurse and get it checked. I had this over Christmas ended up having biopsy in case. It turned out to be necrosis of scar tissue so I had pain killers and some massage, but you never know yourself so best to get it looked at. I finished rads a year ago.
Posts.Title: Breast pain months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I would call your bc nurse and get it checked. I had this over Christmas ended up having biopsy in case. It turned out to be necrosis of scar tissue so I had pain killers and some massage, but you never know yourself so best to get it looked at. I finished rads a year ago.
Posts.Title: Breast pain months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I'm a 38GG and have found bras an issue so have done a lot of research on bra fitting as most of us don't have good fitting bras andÂ  the arm trauma can leave ongoing neck problems if you are not properly supported, I would invest in a bra extender to adapt and soft cup bra that fits you now as you will go back down to it in time. If you have a long back you may find no bra strap is long enough so if you already wear the strap as long as it goes so the bra fits at the bottom of you shoulder blade level it may be a good idea to look for one that can be strapless so you can tie with your own ribbon. Bravissimo do very comfortable night tops with in built bras, often in their sale. They are very thick and can do as an initial comfy top. I still wear mine in the evenings 2 years on as swelling from rads builds up in the day. If you don't get enough support from the cheap asda/jml bras now they will nor give you support post surgery so see how they feel now. Consider theÂ maternity ranges as they are soft with no seems - hand for rads too. Â  Do not remove labels and keep receipts asking manager to agree a return after surgery if you explain they may not fit, often they will extend the return deadline. so get her to sign your receipt. Avoid the bras lined with silver as they will not do you through rads. Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Post Op bra size?

Posts.Content: Be kind to yourself, not only have you had the devastating news we are all taught to fear but alsoÂ major surgery nothing selfish at all just normal let it out cry and scream it will get better but any little thing on a bad day seems to hit so much harder,, your family may be struggling with walking on egg shells around you too a good cuddle and cry together can help. Have you checked out local support for all of you at cancer centres? It can be good to be with others who know what its like or just don't ask those questions or say those really unhelpful phrases because they don't know what elseÂ to say etc.
Posts.Title: How should i be feeling??????

Posts.Content: Hi, I have now had ten sessions of acupuncture through The NHS physio for a back problem and hot flushes. I found that in the first session they dropped from at least 10 a night to 2 or 3 now I don't really get any. The Physio said she has had 100% of her ladies report at least a drop to a manageable level if not totally gone. I may need a couple of top ups in 6 months or so.
Posts.Title: Too Many Hot Flushes

Posts.Content: At Hillingdon the wait fro postal results has now gone down from 10 to 6 weeks 4 if your lucky....but you can call your BC nurse after 2....so I would call. I got a letter from hospital last week so was literally bricking it as knew anything under 2 would be bad...although they ring first.....turned out to be an unrelated rescheduled appointment moving from end June to Feb. 18....never have I been so happy to have a cancelled appointment.
Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: My needles were in my legs, ankles ad feet and one in non affected side's hand on the back between thumb and finger. Ive also had it for neck and back so have had those areas. My lymph nurse did say that she would put them in my non affected arm if it were down to her but it was my choice. I preferred not to.
Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: Can I ask how many sessions of acupuncture you had? I had around 12 in total. A few had 3 week gaps to start and would wear off towards the second week but when I had them regularly they made a big difference. I was told its common to need boosters every 8 months or so. Mine was done through the hospital physio department.
Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: I have acupuncture for hot flushes and neck pain its been amazing for the flushes dropping from around 10 or so a night to an occasional warming in a couple of treatments and neck pain means instead of it waking me nightly and leaving headaches and nausea I only get a mild head once or twice a week with much better movement. Im still going for treatment so hope it will continue to improve. Mine is done through NHS physio.
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Letrozole - acupuncture therapy?

Posts.Content: It depends on you wait and see. I'm a child diner looking after 3under 5 and 2 over. I work 7am to 6pm run a toddlers twice a week with 30 children but wasn't tiered and worked right through just didn't make me tiered although I did sleep well at night.
Posts.Title: How many people worked through RT? Is it doable ?

Posts.Content: T effected my eye sight round one I couldn't see to either read or watch tv it lasted about 3 days and was really scary as I alos lost feeling in toes and fingers to the extent of not feeling cuts on feet and it didn't improve the onc withdrew me from treatment as it wasn't improving odds enough tot take the risk. My eyesight tested back to normal 4 months later. As I didn't have a test during treatment I don't know what my optic nerve was like but they did say it was nerve damage.
Posts.Title: Eye Check

Posts.Content: Glad you got it checked. I had similar experiences to Picturemish but damage after round one meant veins couldn't take a picc so had a Hickman. Im 3 years past chemo and although pain has gone bloods are still difficult. I recommend massaging up the veins and doing arm movements i had physio to help it as it reduced movement in my arm and triggered neck pain. It was extreamly painfull to get dressed and d8dnt look good but now you cant see it and i can carry shopping again.Â
Posts.Title: Pain in arm chemo fec was given 9 dsys ago

Posts.Content: I had also lost on sw before being diagnosed and checked it was okay to continue. As its basic healthy eating I taught the family to cook sw way and then stocked up on what I fancied trying to be as healthy as possible, frozen grapes were good for the sore mouth and yoghurts were good for me. I put on half a stone which is almost off now.
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: Hi. Im about 15 months past chemo and still getting a dry mouth ive had no luck with the gel so had acupuncture today for it, will let you know how it goes.
Posts.Title: help with mouth dryness

Posts.Content: Hi I finished over aÂ year ago...sorry to butt in....take the picc , IÂ  had chemo into arm round one went for picc and too much damage so second round into arm and had to have a Hickman. I still have problems now even after physio. With a line its a lot easier and comfortable. And bloods can be taken from it too.
Posts.Title: JANUARY CHEMO CLUB

Posts.Content: YEP I had several pillows to hand as it takes the weight off, my nurse said "your over thinking it" glad others did the same.
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: I did find the silver lined bras too irritating after rads and even now 10 months later cant wear them for long.
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks for the advice on the gadget. Most of the time I manage the pain is worse in winter especially if I knock my fingers, and was really bad when the nails came off if they got cold....doing seat belts up on the morning school run. My nails didn't start coming off until about 12 weeks later, they are back now but really flacky and my toe noes are very bent and tend to in grow which I don't feel so have to keep an eye on.
Posts.Title: Peripheral sensory neuropathy: how bad should it be allowed to get...

Posts.Content: Thanks for the advice on the gadget. Most of the time I manage the pain is worse in winter especially if I knock my fingers, and was really bad when the nails came off if they got cold....doing seat belts up on the morning school run. My nails didn't start coming off until about 12 weeks later, they are back now but really flacky and my toe noes are very bent and tend to in grow which I don't feel so have to keep an eye on.
Posts.Title: Peripheral sensory neuropathy: how bad should it be allowed to get...

Posts.Content: I have still got numb fingers and toes after having the first and last round of tax in November 14, IÂ  had chemo stopped early because the firs tax numbed me so badly I couldn't feel a cut on Â my toes and my eye sight went blurry for 4 days meaning I couldn't read or watch tv let alone drive. Â My eyes sight went back to normal. You get used to the feeling in your fingers and toes and I find apart from extreme cold and fiddly things like necklaces I also have less strength to undo jars a bit scary as im only 52 and wonder how I will open medicines as I get older as even blister packs now need a knife.
Posts.Title: Peripheral sensory neuropathy: how bad should it be allowed to get...

Posts.Content: I have still got numb fingers and toes after having the first and last round of tax in November 14, IÂ  had chemo stopped early because the firs tax numbed me so badly I couldn't feel a cut on Â my toes and my eye sight went blurry for 4 days meaning I couldn't read or watch tv let alone drive. Â My eyes sight went back to normal. You get used to the feeling in your fingers and toes and I find apart from extreme cold and fiddly things like necklaces I also have less strength to undo jars a bit scary as im only 52 and wonder how I will open medicines as I get older as even blister packs now need a knife.
Posts.Title: Peripheral sensory neuropathy: how bad should it be allowed to get...

Posts.Content: I suffered badly witb dry mouth and then sore tongue. Ive foubd vitamins b6 and b12 make a big difference as did reducing caffine to 1 cup a day. I was really miserable with it. Chewing gum gave temporary releif water only lasted while in the mouth and the gel prescribed by doctor along with washes made no difference Â it was the hospital dentist that suggested vitamins.Â
Posts.Title: Dry mouth

Posts.Content: The biotien stuff made no difference to me and the gel just made a horrible hard lump i would wake up with gaging as it accumulated over the day. Drank all day long woke in night tongue stuck to mouth just horridÂ
Posts.Title: Dry mouth

Posts.Content: I agree we notice them more as they are personal but some are very shocking and not 100% accurate just after starting chemo the ad cam out with the patient sitting alone in a chemo unit all cold and grey and no friends and unlike more recent ads it didn't change to the colourful scene and supportive Â nurse that was terrifying and its only recently that I found that my children actually thought that is what it was like for me my 20 year old was sobbing and I finished chemo last year. I understand the shock value but they do need to think that alongside they are terrifying up to 50% of the population who may go through chemo and make sure it reflects the real situation. The other moment that sticks out for me was going shopping and popping to the ladies I shut the door to be faced with the their is no cure for BC poster. At that time I hadn't been told anything other than I had it and was going fro surgery so I thought OMG I'm going to die I then had a four week wait and still thought I was on borrowed time I really thought that all this was going to give me 10 years as most because the way stats are given. Sometimes they experts forget we don't know it all and are so rushed it doesn't come over so then your in limbo. And if you call them it can be days before you get a return call.
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: I ad this problem and had to take a short course of Tovias to sort it out. Worked like magic and gave my bladder a chance to get back to normal.
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy -Dehydration, waking at night etc.

Posts.Content: I was told always to do lymph massage as a precaution ideally twice a day. If I cut myself I step this up. As already said if there is any sign of infection get some antibiotics. Its always a fear but one that becomes more manageable.
Posts.Title: cut on my hand after lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Your not being selfish, just describing the fears and feelings we all have, unfortunately once your on this treadmill you cant get off until the end so you just have to get on with the bravest face you can grab for the day, hour or minute. My BC nurse had the ability to reduce me to tears no matter how well I thought I was hiding things and that is all it is an act. Every stage for me was scary but not so bad as my imagination once I started. I made a choice not to read too much and never google as that's hard to tell fact from fiction and full of people selling magic cures or horror stories. I would arrange some help for the horses until your recovered from your op and then see what your Oncologist says about the best way forward. Its a tough journey but doable the waiting to start is awful. Good luck x
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to hear of your reoccurrence I don't know how I would handle hearing that. I think you are understandably scared but every treatment has a risk even a tooth extraction as a previous post has said nobody writes about wanting help everything went to plan they get on with that part and worry about other things that are not going right....or have no issue and don't post. I had a full node clearance 2 and a half years ago on a second op neither caused long standing issues but I was more aware of the need to be doing the excercises second time around as the fist op did make movement more limiting, for a week, second op painkillers and exercise from the hour after surgery right through, I even do them now in the shower or when standing around at home. The only long term effect is a slight numbness to the back of the arm which I notice only if I run my fingers down my arm. The swelling you talk about is lymphedema which is a risk if you have injury to the arm, blood pressure taken etc...so you make sure nobody touches that arm, don't get sun burn, clean any cuts and any sign of infection get antibiotics its also worth finding out about lymph massage and doing this daily as it keeps the lymph flowing. If you get it you get treatment by massage and taping or a sleeve but your alive and don't have cancer. What is your prognosis if you don't have the surgery? At 70 you have a lot of living in front of you. Your BC nurse should be able to discuss your worries and help you decide. Hope all goes well
Posts.Title: Terrified at the thought of axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Bras were one of the worst parts of surgery and caused long term problems, Im a size 14 dress size but a 36G bra before surgery after I was a 40HH and had to cut the straps as too tight, Im now a 38G and 2 years past treatment but still a 14 dress size. I found I needed support as the weight of over a stone per boob pulling on scars was too much and was advised to use proper support to stop long term neck and shoulder problems especially as chemo can damage veins, unfortunately the 40 soft cups I found were not supportive enough and caused problems. Bravissimo do support lounge tops in thick material that I wore on sore days and looked like a T-shirt so could wear out....th proper tops are underwired. I did get the silver Royce but it was too itchy for rads so had a struggle getting a soft cup seam free bra and the pull ons other wore did not go over my boobs even in xxxl ....I wore a camisole under the bra which helped. Manufacturers cater for mastectomy's and smaller boobed women larger lumpectomy ladies are left out even the xxxl post surgery sample th hospital found did not fit. Im now back in Underwire and much more comfortable and my boobs are not resting on my tummy. My back is not aching and my neck pain is easing. Bras reduced me to tears many times and cost hundreds of pounds in experiments, I recommend getting a bra extender and looking at maternity ranges.
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I found the not knowing what was awful, I'm a planner and like to be prepared. It seemed every time I went something changed one op, two , rads, chemo stage 2 stage 3, 15 rads, then 18, picc then Â no picc then Hickman. very frustrating and a real rollercoaster .but I'm through it now. Definitely only take things as a rough plan. I had a second op because for some reason no lymph nodes were found after my first so had them all removed, and all clear but still had chemo as my stage went from 2 to 3, apparently the stage can change through the whole sample. It was a scary journey but do able and I guess not as bad as my mind pictured. I just trusted it was the best and decided at the outset it would take a year and it has. On the plus side for me I managed to work through all chemo included with only a few weeks off after surgery and treatment days, you just have to see how your body takes the path which ever one you travel. Sending hugs.
Posts.Title: They didn't say this before!

Posts.Content: A lot seems to depend on your bra size and level of support needed as a G cup the cheap options of asda and primark were not going near me as the compressed tooÂ  much and were agony and even the XXlÂ  support build in tops did not fit (im a size 14 top if I go to Pepperberry who leave boob room and a size 20 normal shape but doesn't fit anywhere but over boobs) My team advised me support was more important than non wired so went back to them as soon as I could as non wired also moved over day pressing on my wound as though the cups were not big enough. I got PJ tops from Bravissimo that were so good quality I could wear as T shirts but non wired. Be prepared to swell up a band size or two...extenders are a cheaper way of using bras through treatment. I also had to cut the straps and tie with ribbon as non were long enough for 3 months or so.
Posts.Title: bra's to wear after surgery

Posts.Content: Bras were one of the worst parts of surgery and caused long term problems, Im a size 14 dress size but a 36G bra before surgery after I was a 40HH and had to cut the straps as too tight, Im now a 38G and 2 years past treatment but still a 14 dress size. I found I needed support as the weight of over a stone per boob pulling on scars was too much and was advised to use proper support to stop long term neck and shoulder problems especially as chemo can damage veins, unfortunately the 40 soft cups I found were not supportive enough and caused problems. Bravissimo do support lounge tops in thick material that I wore on sore days and looked like a T-shirt so could wear out....th proper tops are underwired. I did get the silver Royce but it was too itchy for rads so had a struggle getting a soft cup seam free bra and the pull ons other wore did not go over my boobs even in xxxl ....I wore a camisole under the bra which helped. Manufacturers cater for mastectomy's and smaller boobed women larger lumpectomy ladies are left out even the xxxl post surgery sample th hospital found did not fit. Im now back in Underwire and much more comfortable and my boobs are not resting on my tummy. My back is not aching and my neck pain is easing. Bras reduced me to tears many times and cost hundreds of pounds in experiments, I recommend getting a bra extender and looking at maternity ranges.
Posts.Title: scared to put a bra on after surger for lumpectomy
